revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Eugene Mirman | image = Eugene Mirman by Gage Skidmore.jpg | caption = Mirman at the [[San Diego Comic Con International]] in July 2010 | birth_name = Eugene Boris Mirman | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|7|24}} | birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | residence = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. | medium = Stand-up, television, books, newspaper | nationality = [[Russian-American]] | active = 1991–present | genre = [[Absurdist humor|Absurdism]], [[observational comedy]], satire | subject = [[American culture]], everyday life, [[self-deprecation]] | spouse = Katie Westfall-Tharp (m. 2015) | children = 1 | notable_work = ''[[The Weekly Week]]''
(producer, 1997–1999)
Eugene in ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)|Flight of the Conchords]]''
Yvgeny Mirminsky on ''[[Delocated]]''
Gene Belcher on ''[[Bob's Burgers]]''
Cecil Tunt on ''[[Archer (TV series)|Archer]]'' | signature = | website = [http://eugenemirman.com/ eugenemirman.com] | footnotes = | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Eugene Boris Mirman'''Russian: Евгений Борисович Мирман, ''Yevgeniĭ Borisovich Mirman''; born July 24, 1974.Jackson, Todd (2009). Eugene Mirman. Retrieved on May 13, 2009 from {{cite web |url=http://www.dead-frog.com/comedians/comic/eugene_mirman/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-05-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513072707/http://www.dead-frog.com/comedians/comic/eugene_mirman/ |archivedate=May 13, 2009 |df=mdy-all }}. (born July 24, 1974) is a Russian-born American comedian and writer. Mirman is known for playing Yvgeny Mirminsky on ''[[Delocated]]'', and voicing [[Gene Belcher]] on the animated comedy ''[[Bob's Burgers]]''. ==Early life== Mirman was born in Moscow,http://eugenemirman.com/about/#FAQ {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115165920/http://eugenemirman.com/about/ |date=January 15, 2013 }} to Jewish parents. His family emigrated to the United States when he was four and a half years old.http://eugenemirman.com/about/#Bio {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115165920/http://eugenemirman.com/about/ |date=January 15, 2013 }} Mirman attended [[William Diamond Middle School]] and [[Lexington High School (Massachusetts)|Lexington High School]] in [[Lexington, Massachusetts]], and [[Hampshire College]] in Western [[Massachusetts]]. As part of the college's "choose your own major" program, Mirman graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in comedy, with a one-hour routine as his thesis.{{cite web|last=Mirman|first=Eugene|title=Extended Biography|url=http://eugenemirman.com/about/|accessdate=January 30, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115165920/http://eugenemirman.com/about/|archivedate=January 15, 2013|df=mdy-all}} During summers he attended Camp Tohkomeupog in East Madison, NH. He returned to his high school to deliver its 2009 commencement address.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KZlQd2Eg-9w |title=Eugene Mirman 2009 LHS Commencement Speech |publisher=Youtube.com |date=June 8, 2009 |accessdate=May 1, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130228091747/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KZlQd2Eg-9w |archivedate=February 28, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} He returned to Hampshire to deliver the 2012 commencement speech as well.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-JfKq7clJjw |title=Hampshire College • 2012 Commencement Keynote Speech • Eugene Mirman |publisher=Youtube.com |date= |accessdate=May 1, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102110743/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-JfKq7clJjw |archivedate=January 2, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} ==Career== ===Stand-up career=== In 2004, Mirman released ''The Absurd Nightclub Comedy of Eugene Mirman'', a CD/DVD on Suicide Squeeze Records. The album was voted one of the Best Albums of 2004 by both ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' and ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]]'' New York. His second album, ''[[En Garde, Society]]'' was released by [[Sub Pop]] in 2006. Three years later, Mirman released another comedy album titled ''God Is a Twelve-Year-Old Boy with Aspergers'' which was recorded in Chicago at the Lakeshore Theatre.{{cite web|url=http://www.subpop.com/bio/eugene_mirman|title=Eugene Mirman|author=Sub Pop Records|work=Sub Pop Records|accessdate=December 20, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131216193715/http://www.subpop.com/bio/eugene_mirman|archivedate=December 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}} In 2012, Mirman released ''An Evening Of Comedy In A Fake, Underground Laboratory.''{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2514162/|title=Eugene Mirman: An Evening of Comedy in a Fake Underground Laboratory (TV Movie 2012)|date=December 21, 2012|work=IMDb|accessdate=December 20, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160405002838/http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2514162/|archivedate=April 5, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Mirman has appeared at the [[U.S. Comedy Arts Festival]] in [[Aspen, Colorado]], the [[Just for Laughs|Just for Laughs Festival]] in [[Montreal]], [[Bumbershoot]], and [[South by Southwest]]. He co-produced the weekly standup-variety show Invite Them Up with [[Bobby Tisdale]] and Holly Schlesinger, which won a Nightlife Award. He currently produces Pretty Good Friends (formerly Tearing the Veil of Maya) at Union Hall in Park Slope, Brooklyn with Julie Smith, which has been voted the best comedy night in New York City by New York Magazine. Mirman, much like [[David Cross]] and [[Patton Oswalt]], is known to often perform in rock clubs and theaters as opposed to traditional comedy clubs. Often touring the United States, Mirman occasionally opens for the comedy troupe [[Stella (U.S. TV series)|Stella]] (former members of [[The State (1993 TV series)|The State]]). He has opened for various bands such as [[The Shins]] and toured with [[Modest Mouse]], [[Yo La Tengo]], [[Gogol Bordello]], [[Andrew Bird]], and [[Cake (band)|Cake]]. Mirman also toured with [[Patton Oswalt]], [[Brian Posehn]] and [[Maria Bamford]] on the [[Comedians of Comedy]] tour. He has toured as an opener for [[Flight of the Conchords]] and with [[Andy Kindler]] and [[Marc Maron]] in ''Stand Uppity''. He plays the character Eugene in the ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)|Flight of the Conchords]]'' [[HBO]] television series. In January 2010, Mirman performed standup on the ''[[John Oliver's New York Stand Up Show]]'' on Comedy Central.{{cite web |author=Photo courtesy of Comedy Central, Lead photo by Gavin Bond |url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2009/11/john-oliver-gets-his-own-tv-show.html |title=John Oliver's TV Show to Feature Eugene Mirman, Paul F. Tompkins, Janeane Garofalo, Many More |publisher=Pastemagazine.com |date=November 30, 2009 |accessdate=May 1, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130503000217/http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2009/11/john-oliver-gets-his-own-tv-show.html |archivedate=May 3, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} Mirman's Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival has been running since 2008.{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.interviewmagazine.com/blogs/culture/2011-09-20/the-erudite-absurdist-eugene-mirman|title=The Erudite Absurdist: Eugene Mirman – Page|publisher=Interview Magazine|date=|accessdate=April 2, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111024223140/http://www.interviewmagazine.com/blogs/culture/2011-09-20/the-erudite-absurdist-eugene-mirman|archivedate=October 24, 2011|df=mdy-all}} On April 10, 2015, Mirman filmed a live stand-up special in [[Tucson, AZ]], directed by [[Bobcat Goldthwait]]. The special was released on Netflix in 2015 as ''Eugene Mirman: Vegan on His Way to the Complain Store''. ===Television career=== Mirman has appeared on several TV shows, including ''[[Late Night with Conan O'Brien]]'', [[HBO]]'s ''[[Flight of the Conchords (TV series)|Flight of the Conchords]]'', the BBC's ''[[Russell Howard's Good News]]'', ''[[Comedy Central Presents]]'', ''[[Delocated]]'',{{cite web |url=http://www.brooklynvegan.com/archives/2008/03/jon_glaser_on_a.html |title=Jon Glaser on Adult Swim, a NYC Human Giant show, Clipse |publisher=Brooklynvegan.com |date=March 24, 2008 |accessdate=May 1, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531191121/http://www.brooklynvegan.com/archives/2008/03/jon_glaser_on_a.html |archivedate=May 31, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} ''[[Aqua Teen Hunger Force]]'', [[Comedy Central]]'s ''[[Premium Blend]]'', [[VH1]], ''[[Third Watch]]'', [[Cartoon Network]]'s ''[[Home Movies (TV series)|Home Movies]]'', ''[[Cheap Seats (TV series)|Cheap Seats]]'', ''[[Lucy, the Daughter of the Devil]]'' and more. He also played a spokes-potato on [[Food Network]]. In late 2010, Mirman performed on the [[Comedy Central]] show ''[[The Benson Interruption]]''. On February 21, 2011, Mirman appeared on ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' as a fertility clown. On April 4, 2013, Mirman provided the voice for Cecil Tunt, multi-millionaire brother of Cheryl/Carol Tunt on [[FX (TV channel)|FX]]'s ''[[Archer (TV series)|Archer]]''. On March 13, 2016, Mirman appeared on "[[Last Week Tonight]]" as a hacker. Mirman currently voices the character Gene Belcher on the Fox animated series ''[[Bob's Burgers]]''.{{Cite journal|url=http://www.fox.com/bobsburgers/bios/gene/|publisher=Fox|title=Bob's Burgers|postscript={{inconsistent citations}}|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110112180401/http://www.fox.com/bobsburgers/bios/gene|archivedate=January 12, 2011|df=mdy-all}} Mirman lent his guest voice to a character named Emperor Keith Merman in the [[Netflix]] original ''[[The Adventures of Puss in Boots]]''. ===Radio and podcasts=== In January 2009, Mirman released a satirical self-help book entitled ''The Will to Whatevs''.{{cite web |last=Mirman |first=Eugene |url=http://www.harpercollins.ca/books/9780061346187/The_Will_to_Whatevs/index.aspx |title=Harper Collins Website |publisher=Harpercollins.ca |date=March 24, 2010 |accessdate=May 1, 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924025053/http://www.harpercollins.ca/books/9780061346187/The_Will_to_Whatevs/index.aspx |archivedate=September 24, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} He often appears on ''[[StarTalk (podcast)|StarTalk]] Radio'', hosted by [[Neil deGrasse Tyson]].{{cite web |url=http://startalkradio.net/ |title=StarTalk Radio Show by Neil deGrasse Tyson | first and only popular commercial radio program devoted to all things space |publisher=Startalkradio.net |date= |accessdate=April 2, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424152732/http://www.startalkradio.net/ |archivedate=April 24, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} He has also appeared several times on [[StarTalk (2015 TV series)|the TV adaptation]]. Mirman guest starred as an "[[Expert witness]]" on humorist [[John Hodgman]]'s podcast ''[[Judge John Hodgman]]''.{{cite web|author=MaxFun Intern|url=http://www.maximumfun.org/judge-john-hodgman/judge-john-hodgman-episode-134-right-remain-silent|title=Judge John Hodgman Episode 134: The Right to Remain Silent|publisher=[[Maximum Fun]]|date=November 14, 2013|accessdate=December 2, 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203000623/http://www.maximumfun.org/judge-john-hodgman/judge-john-hodgman-episode-134-right-remain-silent|archivedate=December 3, 2013|df=mdy-all}} Mirman appeared on [[Ken Reid (comedian)|Ken Reid]]'s ''TV Guidance Counselor Podcast'' on April 24, 2015. The episode was recorded live as part of the 2015 Eugene Mirman Comedy Festival in Boston. Mirman plays a supporting role of Benny the gerbil on the children's podcast ''This Podcast Has Fleas'' in 2017. {{cite web|url=http://www.wnycstudios.org/shows/fleas/|title=This Podcast Has Fleas - WNYC Studios - Podcasts|author=|date=|website=wnycstudios|accessdate=April 25, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180107000710/https://www.wnycstudios.org/shows/fleas|archivedate=January 7, 2018|df=mdy-all}} ==Personal life== Mirman married his longtime girlfriend Katie Westfall-Tharp on [[Labor Day]] 2015.{{cite web|last1=Parker|first1=Ian|title=Funny-Sounding|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/01/25/funny-sounding|website=The New Yorker|accessdate=19 January 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160118084253/http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/01/25/funny-sounding|archivedate=January 18, 2016|df=mdy-all}} Together they have a son (born 2016).{{cite web|title=Eugene Mirman: Burger On A Sesame Seed Pun|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=510761232|website=NPR.org|accessdate=26 January 2017|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170123115000/http://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=510761232|archivedate=January 23, 2017|df=mdy-all}} ==Discography== * ''The Absurd Nightclub Comedy of Eugene Mirman'' (2004) * ''Invite Them Up'' (2005) * ''[[En Garde, Society|En Garde, Society!]]'' (2006) * ''Comedians of Comedy 3" Tour CD'' (2006) * ''[[God Is a Twelve-Year-Old Boy with Asperger's]]'' (2009) * ''An Evening of Comedy In a Fake Underground Laboratory'' (2012) * ''I'm Sorry (You're Welcome)'' (2015) ==Bibliography== * ''The Will to Whatevs'' (2009) ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Eugene Mirman}} * [http://www.eugenemirman.com Eugene Mirman official website] * [https://www.myspace.com/eugenemirman Eugene Mirman on] MySpace * {{IMDb name|id=1483349}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mirman, Eugene}} [[Category:Suicide Squeeze Records artists]]
